title: Java Developer
summary: An entry level Java developer with Java development experience or similar academic background.
RoadMap:
"1. Learn Core Java Fundamentals: Start with basic concepts like data types, operators, control structures, and object-oriented programming (OOP) principles. 
2. Practice Java Coding: Solve coding challenges on platforms like HackerRank, LeetCode, or Codewars to build your problem-solving skills. 
3. Explore Java Frameworks: Familiarize yourself with popular Java frameworks such as Spring, Spring Boot, or Hibernate, which are commonly used in enterprise applications. 
4. Learn about Databases: Understand database concepts, SQL, and how to interact with databases using Java. 
5. Build Projects: Create personal projects to showcase your Java skills and experience. These could range from simple console applications to more complex web applications.
6. Consider further certifications: Explore other certifications such as Oracle Certified Associate, Java SE Programmer, or other vendor-specific certifications that align with your career interests.\

title: Junior Java Developer
summary: These industry leading products support the collection of tolls and the associated operations for a number of the country’s largest tolling agencies.
RecommendedCertifications: \"Oracle Certified Java Programmer, Spring Professional Certification\
RoadMap: \"1. Learn Core Java Fundamentals: Start with the basics of Java, including data types, operators, control structures, and object-oriented programming concepts. 2. Master Java Collections Framework: Understand how to use Java’s built-in collections like ArrayList, LinkedList, HashMap, etc. 3. Learn Spring Framework: Spring is a popular Java framework used for building enterprise applications. Focus on Spring Core, Spring MVC, and Spring Data. 4. Database Interaction: Learn how to interact with databases using JDBC or other ORMs (Object-Relational Mappers). 5. Practice Coding: Solve coding challenges on platforms like LeetCode, HackerRank, or Codewars to improve your problem-solving skills. 6. Build Projects: Create personal projects to demonstrate your Java skills and understanding of Spring. This can include building a simple web application, a REST API, or a small utility program. 7. Learn Testing: Learn how to write unit and integration tests for your Java code. This is important for ensuring the quality of your work. 8. Version Control: Learn how to use Git and GitHub for version control, which is crucial in collaborative development environments. 9. Cloud Technologies (Optional): Consider learning cloud platforms like AWS, Azure, or GCP, as many Java applications are deployed on the cloud. 10. Continuous Learning: Keep learning new technologies and best practices in Java and related areas. Stay updated with the latest trends in the industry.\

title: Java Developer
summary: Duration: Fulltime job, 40 hours per week.
RoadMap: \"Learn core java, multithreading, spring boot, microservices, and cloud technologies.\

title: Java Backend Developer I
summary: Collaborate with senior developers and stakeholders to understand project requirements and translate them into technical specifications.
RecommendedCertifications: \"AWS Certified Developer - Associate\",\"Oracle Certified Professional, Java SE Programmer\
RoadMap: \"1. Learn Core Java Fundamentals: Start with the basics of Java syntax, data types, object-oriented programming (OOP) concepts, and exception handling. Resources like online courses (Udemy, Coursera), tutorials, and books can help. 2. Master Java Collections Framework: Understand how to use different data structures like ArrayList, LinkedList, HashMap, etc., efficiently.  3. Database Management: Learn SQL and NoSQL databases (e.g., MySQL, PostgreSQL, MongoDB). Practice writing queries and managing databases. 4. Spring Framework: Spring is widely used in Java backend development. Learn Spring Boot, Spring MVC, and Spring Data for building robust and scalable applications. 5. Microservices Architecture: Gain knowledge of designing and building applications using microservices.  6. Cloud Technologies: Familiarize yourself with cloud platforms like AWS, Azure, or Google Cloud.  7. RESTful APIs: Learn to design, develop, and test RESTful APIs using frameworks like Spring REST.  8. Testing and Debugging: Practice writing unit tests, integration tests, and debugging techniques.  9. Version Control (Git): Learn how to use Git for managing code changes and collaborating with other developers.  10. Continuous Integration and Continuous Deployment (CI/CD): Learn CI/CD processes to automate the building, testing, and deployment of your applications.  11. Build Projects: Hands-on experience is crucial. Build personal projects to solidify your skills and showcase your abilities to potential employers. Consider building a REST API that interacts with a database or a simple microservice.\
